Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.coindesk.com/will-fiat-backed-stablecoins-pass-legal-muster-with-the-sec-and-cftc%3famp

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Cc-peg and several other methods of stablecoins might prove fruitful in the future

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems that decentralized solutions end up in regulatory safe harbors, likely due to the problem of enforcing against individual users. its one thing to go after companies running centralized solutions, another to go after individuals en masse, who could well be voters

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so decentralization isnt just a good ideal to strive for, it appears to have regulatory benefits also

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and maybe this is no coincidence, as with a decentralized solution there isnt trust placed in a single organization with control over the funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as we see with the CB ARRR token, centralized tokens even if used on a decentralized blockchain, end up devolving to trusting the issuer

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: In terms of money related stablecoins it does appear the only way to go is decentralized in all aspects like @jl777c said .  I think though we will see a class of stablecoins that does rely on trusted parties but has a clear and common legal structure to deal with issues that arise .   Merchants using blockchains directly for commerce for example,  not in the sense of using crypto to pay for goods, but that the merchants inventory is directly interact-able with customers via atomic swaps.   Basically will be a workaround to not being able to barter physical goods through digital media,  but you can barter titles through digital media.    Consignment would be another example of a stablecoin class.
